questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in patients with stable angina?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Normal cardiac enzymes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stable angina is associated with normal cardiac enzymes because there is no myocardial injury or necrosis in this condition.
  • ➤ normal cardiac enzymes

questions.text: What is the maximum predicted heart rate in a 45-year-old gentleman on exercise tolerance test?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 175/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The maximum predicted heart rate during exercise is calculated as 220 minus the person's age . For a 45-year-old, the MHR is 175 beats per minute .
  • ➤ maximum predicted heart rate
  • ➤ 220 minus the person's age
  • ➤ 175 beats per minute

questions.text: All of the following statements regarding myocardial stunning are true EXCEPT:

options.label: A
options.text: Stunning is a state of depressed myocardial function due to chronic hypoperfusion

options.label: B
options.text: Stunning can be global or regional

options.label: C
options.text: Oxygen free radicals and excess intracellular calcium likely contribute to stunning

options.label: D
options.text: Stunning affects both systolic and diastolic function

questions.correct_answer: A. Stunning is a state of depressed myocardial function due to chronic hypoperfusion
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stunning is a state of depressed myocardial function due to chronic hypoperfusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myocardial stunning occurs after acute ischemic injury or reperfusion and is not associated with chronic hypoperfusion . It involves temporary, reversible dysfunction of the heart muscle without permanent damage.
  • ➤ acute ischemic injury
  • ➤ reperfusion
  • ➤ not associated with chronic hypoperfusion

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest finding in patient with suspect acute MI?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Tall T wave

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The earliest ECG finding in acute MI is typically the tall, peaked T wave , which reflects early ischemic changes.
  • ➤ earliest ECG finding in acute MI
  • ➤ tall, peaked T wave

questions.text: A 45-year-old is brought to the ER with sudden onset chest pain, diaphoresis, and giddiness. On arrival, BP is 86/60 mmHg. Immediate ECG is performed (see image). Which of the following is useful in the management of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  D) IV fluids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of inferior MI with associated right ventricular infarction , avoid preload-reducing agents like nitrates or morphine. IV fluids are the first-line treatment to support preload and maintain cardiac output in hypotensive patients.
  • ➤ inferior MI with associated right ventricular infarction
  • ➤ IV fluids

questions.text: Falsely low BNP values can be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Obesity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Obesity is a key condition where BNP values may be falsely low , despite the presence of heart failure symptoms, due to reduced myocardial stretch and altered hormone metabolism.
  • ➤ Obesity
  • ➤ falsely low

questions.text: Risk of sudden cardiac death in heart failure is maximum among which of the following NYHA class?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Class II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Patients with NYHA Class II heart failure have the highest proportion of sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias, even though total mortality is higher in more severe classes like Class IV.
  • ➤ NYHA Class II
  • ➤ proportion of sudden cardiac death

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is characterized by myocyte disarray on myocardial biopsy?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) Fabry disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fabry disease is associated with myocyte disarray on myocardial biopsy and causes reversible hypertrophic cardiomyopathy . It is important to differentiate this condition from other types of cardiomyopathies based on its clinical presentation and pathology.
  • ➤ Fabry disease
  • ➤ myocyte disarray
  • ➤ reversible hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

questions.text: Brockenbrough-Braunwald-Morrow sign is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypertrophic Cardiomyopathy (HCM)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Brockenbrough-Braunwald-Morrow sign is a diagnostic hallmark of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM) and reflects the hemodynamic effects of left ventricular outflow tract obstruction following premature ventricular contractions.
  • ➤ Brockenbrough-Braunwald-Morrow sign
  • ➤ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy (HCM)

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfans syndrome developed worsening chest pain and dyspnea. On examination asymmetrical pulses was noted. CXR showed widened mediastinum. CT angiogram was done to evaluate this patient. Which of the following is true regarding management of the patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Operative repair indicated if diameter >5.5 cm

questions.correct_answer: B. Operative repair if diameter >4-5 cm
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Operative repair if diameter >4-5 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with Marfan syndrome , operative repair of the aorta is generally recommended when the aortic diameter reaches 4 to 5 cm to prevent aortic dissection, a life-threatening complication of the condition.
  • ➤ Marfan syndrome
  • ➤ operative repair of the aorta
  • ➤ 4 to 5 cm

questions.text: What is the likely cardiac axis marked A in the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Right axis deviation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cardiac axis labeled A represents right axis deviation , which falls between +90° and +180° on the cardiac axis circle.
  • ➤ cardiac axis labeled A
  • ➤ right axis deviation
  • ➤ +90° and +180°

questions.text: 40-year-old on anti-depressants presented with giddiness and fatigue. On arrival Bp 80/60mmhg. ECG done showed the following. Which of the following drugs is appropriate in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Intravenous sodium bicarbonate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity , with signs such as ventricular arrhythmias and wide QRS complexes , the drug of choice for management is intravenous sodium bicarbonate .
  • ➤ tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) toxicity
  • ➤ ventricular arrhythmias
  • ➤ wide QRS complexes
  • ➤ intravenous sodium bicarbonate

questions.text: 40-year-old male with recent post CABG status presented with chest pain. On arrival BP was found to be 60/30mmHg with HR of 30/min. ECG showed narrow complex arrhythmia. Patient immediately received three boluses of IV atropine. While awaiting Transcutaneous pacing, which of the following is next appropriate step in the management?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) IV Dopamine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of severe symptomatic bradycardia unresponsive to atropine, IV dopamine or epinephrine is recommended while awaiting transcutaneous pacing. Avoid agents like norepinephrine and dobutamine in these settings.

questions.text: 30-year-old IT employee developed sudden loss of consciousness on listening to ambulance alarm. On arrival to ER patient was hemodynamically stable. She gives h/o similar episodes in the past. ECG done given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Congenital Long QT syndrome type 2
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Congenital Long QT syndrome type 2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Congenital Long QT syndrome type 2 is often triggered by sudden auditory stimuli and is characterized by a prolonged QT interval with arrhythmias, particularly in response to loud noises.
  • ➤ Congenital Long QT syndrome type 2

questions.text: 30-year-old male presented with episodes of palpitation. On arrival patient stable. ECG given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Brugada syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome is characterized by a pseudo-right bundle branch block pattern and coved-type ST elevation in leads V1 to V3 , which can predispose to sudden cardiac death due to ventricular arrhythmias.
  • ➤ Brugada syndrome
  • ➤ pseudo-right bundle branch block
  • ➤ coved-type ST elevation
  • ➤ V1 to V3

questions.text: A pregnant lady, G2P1L1, currently 37 weeks pregnant, presented with worsening headache, blurring of vision, and reduced perception of fetal movements. On arrival, BP was 200/100 mmHg. The patient’s ECG is given below. Which of the following is the best management for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) IV MgSO₄

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of torsades de pointes , particularly in the setting of preeclampsia , the best management is IV magnesium sulfate , which can effectively treat the arrhythmia and prevent further complications.
  • ➤ torsades de pointes
  • ➤ preeclampsia
  • ➤ IV magnesium sulfate

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication for thrombolysis in stroke?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thrombolysis in stroke has strict contraindications, including uncontrolled hypertension (BP >185/110 mmHg) , recent gastrointestinal bleeding , and major surgery in the last 14 days due to the heightened risk of life-threatening bleeding.
  • ➤ uncontrolled hypertension (BP >185/110 mmHg)
  • ➤ recent gastrointestinal bleeding
  • ➤ major surgery in the last 14 days

questions.text: All of the following are components of the ABCD2 score, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Creatinine levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ABCD2 score helps assess stroke risk after a TIA and includes factors such as age , blood pressure , clinical features , duration of symptoms , and diabetes . Creatinine levels are not part of this score.
  • ➤ ABCD2 score
  • ➤ age
  • ➤ blood pressure
  • ➤ clinical features
  • ➤ duration of symptoms
  • ➤ diabetes
  • ➤ Creatinine levels

questions.text: Which of the following strategies does not have a mortality benefit in ARDS?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Corticosteroids

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In non-COVID-19 ARDS , corticosteroids do not provide a mortality benefit. In contrast, low tidal volume ventilation , high PEEP , and prone ventilation are all strategies associated with better outcomes and improved survival in ARDS.
  • ➤ non-COVID-19 ARDS
  • ➤ corticosteroids
  • ➤ low tidal volume ventilation
  • ➤ high PEEP
  • ➤ prone ventilation

questions.text: What is the most common site for hypertensive hemorrhage?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Putamen

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The putamen is the most common site for hypertensive hemorrhage , followed by the thalamus . This is due to the vulnerability of the small blood vessels in the basal ganglia to damage from chronic hypertension.
  • ➤ putamen
  • ➤ hypertensive hemorrhage
  • ➤ thalamus

questions.text: A 60-year-old reformed smoker with COPD (GOLD Category E) presents with worsening dyspnea and cough. The patient was started on salbutamol nebulizations, IV antibiotics, and corticosteroids. Repeat ABG shows: pH: 7.25 pCO2: 60 mmHg pO2: 49.5 mmHg RR: 26/min Which is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oxygen with NIV (Non-Invasive Ventilation)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with acute hypercapnic respiratory failure due to COPD exacerbation , the next appropriate step is to initiate Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV) with supplemental oxygen to improve gas exchange and avoid invasive mechanical ventilation if possible.
  • ➤ acute hypercapnic respiratory failure
  • ➤ COPD exacerbation
  • ➤ Non-Invasive Ventilation (NIV)

questions.text: Autosomal recessive inactivating mutations in Calcium Sensing Receptor cause?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Neonatal severe hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Autosomal recessive inactivating mutations in the calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR) lead to Neonatal Severe Hyperparathyroidism (NSHPT) , characterized by severe hypercalcemia and hyperparathyroidism from birth.
  • ➤ calcium-sensing receptor (CaSR)
  • ➤ Neonatal Severe Hyperparathyroidism (NSHPT)

questions.text: Giant aneurysms have a diameter of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) >2.5 cm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Giant aneurysms are those with a diameter of more than 2.5 cm and carry a higher risk of rupture and complications.
  • ➤ Giant aneurysms
  • ➤ more than 2.5 cm

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with a 4-week history of dry coughing and dyspnea with exertion. She has been receiving treatment for her swollen joints and morning stiffness for a few years. Inspiratory fine crackles are audible on auscultation. A basilar, subpleural, and bilateral honeycombing pattern is visible on HRCT. Which of the following patterns is the patient's pulmonary function test (PFT) most likely to display?
questions.correct_answer: C. FEV1/FVC ratio >0.7 and DLCO decreases
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) FEV1/FVC ratio >0.7 and DLCO decreases

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In interstitial lung disease (ILD) , such as idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis , the FEV1/FVC ratio is typically >0.7 , and the DLCO is decreased due to impaired gas exchange caused by alveolar fibrosis.
  • ➤ interstitial lung disease (ILD)
  • ➤ idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis
  • ➤ FEV1/FVC ratio
  • ➤ >0.7
  • ➤ DLCO is decreased

questions.text: Hamman-Rich syndrome is a synonym of which of the following disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acute interstitial pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hamman-Rich syndrome is an older term for acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP) , a rapidly progressive form of interstitial lung disease that can lead to severe respiratory failure.
  • ➤ Hamman-Rich syndrome
  • ➤ acute interstitial pneumonia (AIP)

questions.text: Lymphocytic Hypophysitis most commonly occurs in which of the following patients?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Postpartum women

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lymphocytic hypophysitis most commonly occurs in pregnant and postpartum women , and can also be seen with the use of immune checkpoint inhibitors. The most important differential diagnosis is Sheehan syndrome , especially in the postpartum period.
  • ➤ Lymphocytic hypophysitis
  • ➤ pregnant and postpartum women
  • ➤ Sheehan syndrome

questions.text: Anton’s syndrome is produced due to lesion in?

options.label: A
options.text: Bilateral infarction in the distal ACAs

options.label: B
options.text: Bilateral infarction in the distal MCAs

options.label: C
options.text: Bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs

questions.correct_answer: C. Bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bilateral infarction in the distal PCAs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anton’s syndrome is caused by bilateral infarctions in the distal posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs) , leading to cortical blindness with denial of blindness (visual anosognosia) .
  • ➤ Anton’s syndrome
  • ➤ bilateral infarctions in the distal posterior cerebral arteries (PCAs)
  • ➤ cortical blindness
  • ➤ denial of blindness (visual anosognosia)

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady presented with significant weight loss, fatigue, myalgia, and difficulty getting up from bed or from a squatting position. Physical examination revealed papular lesions over the knuckles and fine crackles on auscultation with a restrictive PFT pattern. HRCT was performed and revealed interstitial lung disease. What is the expected lung biopsy finding in this patient. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anti-Synthetase syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of proximal muscle weakness , dermatomyositis , and interstitial lung disease strongly suggests Anti-Synthetase syndrome , most commonly associated with anti-Jo-1 antibodies .
  • ➤ proximal muscle weakness
  • ➤ dermatomyositis
  • ➤ interstitial lung disease
  • ➤ Anti-Synthetase syndrome
  • ➤ anti-Jo-1 antibodies

questions.text: Subclavian steal is seen in which of the following lesions?

options.label: A
options.text: Occlusion distal to the origin of the vertebral artery

options.label: B
options.text: Occlusion in V1 segment of vertebral artery

options.label: C
options.text: Occlusion proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery

options.label: D
options.text: Occlusion in V2 segment of vertebral artery

questions.correct_answer: C. Occlusion proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occlusion proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subclavian steal syndrome is caused by occlusion or stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery , resulting in reversal of vertebral artery blood flow and symptoms of vertebrobasilar insufficiency.
  • ➤ Subclavian steal syndrome
  • ➤ occlusion or stenosis of the subclavian artery proximal to the origin of the vertebral artery

questions.text: All of the following are true about pituitary tumors, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Pituitary adenomas frequently extend in a suprasellar direction

options.label: C
options.text: Headache severity correlates with adenoma size or extension

options.label: D
options.text: Suprasellar extension can lead to visual loss

questions.correct_answer: C. Headache severity correlates with adenoma size or extension
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Headache severity correlates with adenoma size or extension

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Headaches are common in patients with pituitary adenomas , but the severity of the headache does not correlate with the size or extension of the tumor. Visual loss can occur due to suprasellar extension and compression of the optic chiasm .
  • ➤ pituitary adenomas
  • ➤ severity of the headache does not correlate
  • ➤ suprasellar extension
  • ➤ optic chiasm

questions.text: Which of the following describes the best method to diagnose bronchial asthma?
questions.correct_answer: D. Reversible obstruction demonstration on PFT.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Reversible obstruction demonstration on PFT

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best method to diagnose bronchial asthma is by demonstrating reversible airway obstruction using pulmonary function tests (PFTs) , typically through spirometry .
  • ➤ bronchial asthma
  • ➤ reversible airway obstruction
  • ➤ pulmonary function tests (PFTs)
  • ➤ spirometry

questions.text: What is the screening test for Acromegaly?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Serum IGF-1 levels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The screening test for acromegaly is serum IGF-1 levels , as it reliably reflects the chronic overproduction of growth hormone.
  • ➤ screening test for acromegaly
  • ➤ serum IGF-1 levels

questions.text: The Gold's criteria for very severe COPD is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Very severe COPD according to GOLD criteria is defined as FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% of predicted , with or without chronic respiratory failure.
  • ➤ Very severe COPD
  • ➤ GOLD criteria
  • ➤ FEV1/FVC <0.7
  • ➤ FEV1 <30% of predicted

questions.text: In which of the following situations would NIV be considered contraindicated?

options.label: A
options.text: Acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)

options.label: B
options.text: Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure in an individual with ARDS

options.label: D
options.text: Decompensated systolic heart failure without acute myocardial ischemia

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Acute myocardial infarction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ NIV is contraindicated in acute myocardial infarction due to the potential for increased intrathoracic pressure to impair coronary perfusion, posing a risk in the setting of cardiac ischemia.

questions.text: Which of the following features are characteristic of Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MODY is characterized by autosomal dominant inheritance , early onset hyperglycemia , and impaired insulin secretion , distinguishing it from other forms of diabetes.
  • ➤ MODY
  • ➤ autosomal dominant inheritance
  • ➤ early onset hyperglycemia
  • ➤ impaired insulin secretion

questions.text: All of the following are cardinal motor features of Parkinson’s disease, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  C) Masked facies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cardinal motor features of Parkinson’s disease include tremor , rigidity , bradykinesia , and postural instability . Masked facies is a common feature but not a cardinal motor feature.
  • ➤ Parkinson’s disease
  • ➤ tremor
  • ➤ rigidity
  • ➤ bradykinesia
  • ➤ postural instability
  • ➤ Masked facies

questions.text: All of the following are seen in fasting state, except?

options.label: C
options.text: Increased glucose uptake in skeletal muscle and fat

questions.correct_answer: C. Increased glucose uptake in skeletal muscle and fat
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Increased glucose uptake in skeletal muscle and fat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the fasting state , processes like gluconeogenesis , glycogenolysis , and lipolysis increase, while glucose uptake in skeletal muscle and fat decreases due to low insulin levels.
  • ➤ fasting state
  • ➤ gluconeogenesis
  • ➤ glycogenolysis
  • ➤ lipolysis
  • ➤ glucose uptake

questions.text: Bull’s head sign on Radionuclide bone scan is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) SAPHO syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Bull’s head sign" on a radionuclide bone scan is a diagnostic imaging feature seen in SAPHO syndrome , reflecting involvement of the sternum and clavicles.
  • ➤ SAPHO syndrome

questions.text: A 60-year-old female is referred for chronic cough and dyspnea with exertion. Over the past year, her cough and dyspnea have steadily gotten worse. According to pulmonary function testing, the FVC:72%, FEV1: 80%, DLCO 38%. CT given below. Lung biopsy done to evaluate cause of CT abnormalities reveals foci of scarring that are dispersed and surrounded by healthy lung parenchyma and fibroblasts. Which of the following is the appropriate therapy for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pirfenidone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF) , the appropriate treatment involves the use of anti-fibrotic agents such as Pirfenidone or Nintedanib to slow the progression of fibrosis. Immunosuppressive therapy should be avoided in IPF.
  • ➤ Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF)
  • ➤ anti-fibrotic agents
  • ➤ Pirfenidone
  • ➤ Nintedanib
  • ➤ Immunosuppressive therapy

questions.text: Levodopa-induced motor complications are seen more commonly in all of the following patients, except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Old patients

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Levodopa-induced motor complications are more commonly seen in patients with severe disease , those on higher doses of levodopa , and women , but they are less common in older patients .
  • ➤ Levodopa-induced motor complications
  • ➤ severe disease
  • ➤ higher doses of levodopa
  • ➤ women
  • ➤ less common in older patients

questions.text: The definitive treatment for Hepato-renal syndrome is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Orthotopic liver transplantation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The definitive treatment for Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS) is orthotopic liver transplantation , as it targets the underlying cause of liver failure and can restore kidney function. Terlipressin and albumin are supportive therapies used while awaiting transplantation.
  • ➤ definitive treatment
  • ➤ Hepatorenal Syndrome (HRS)
  • ➤ orthotopic liver transplantation
  • ➤ Terlipressin and albumin

questions.text: Drug approved in delaying the onset of stage 3 T1D in high-risk individuals ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Teplizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Teplizumab is the first drug approved to delay the onset of stage 3 Type 1 Diabetes in high-risk individuals by modulating the autoimmune process involved in the destruction of pancreatic beta cells.
  • ➤ Teplizumab
  • ➤ delay the onset of stage 3 Type 1 Diabetes

questions.text: Class IV Lupus Nephritis consist of ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diffuse Lupus Nephritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Class IV Lupus Nephritis is also known as Diffuse Lupus Nephritis , characterized by the involvement of more than 50% of the glomeruli, and is the most severe form of lupus-related kidney disease.
  • ➤ Diffuse Lupus Nephritis

questions.text: All the following are complications due to peritoneal dialysis therapy EXCEPT?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypoglycemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia is not a complication of peritoneal dialysis . The common metabolic complications include hyperglycemia , hypoproteinemia , hypertriglyceridemia , and hyperphosphatemia .
  • ➤ Hypoglycemia
  • ➤ not
  • ➤ peritoneal dialysis
  • ➤ hyperglycemia
  • ➤ hypoproteinemia
  • ➤ hypertriglyceridemia
  • ➤ hyperphosphatemia

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody is detected by Dilute Russel viper venom test ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Lupus anticoagulant

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test (dRVVT) is specifically used to detect lupus anticoagulant , an important marker for antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • ➤ Dilute Russell Viper Venom Test (dRVVT)
  • ➤ lupus anticoagulant

questions.text: In a Parkinson’s patient who developed Dementia, which of the following drugs are stopped first?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anticholinergics

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a Parkinson’s patient who develops dementia, anticholinergic drugs are stopped first due to their significant potential to worsen cognitive function and contribute to dementia.
  • ➤ anticholinergic drugs

questions.text: The fructosamine assay reflects the glycemic status for the prior:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 Weeks

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The fructosamine assay provides information on glycemic control over the past 2 weeks and is useful for short-term monitoring.
  • ➤ fructosamine assay
  • ➤ 2 weeks

questions.text: Placement of hemodialysis catheter at which site is associated with greater risk of stenosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subclavian

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The subclavian vein is associated with a greater risk of stenosis when used for hemodialysis catheter placement, which can complicate future vascular access options for dialysis.
  • ➤ subclavian vein
  • ➤ greater risk of stenosis

questions.text: All of the following vasculitis are due to the production of antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA), except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein) is not associated with ANCA production, distinguishing it from other vasculitides like Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis, and Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis, which are ANCA-associated.
  • ➤ IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein)

questions.text: Swan-neck deformity in Rheumatoid arthritis is defined as?

options.label: A
options.text: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint

options.label: B
options.text: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint

options.label: C
options.text: Subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint

questions.correct_answer: B. Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Swan-neck deformity in rheumatoid arthritis is characterized by hyperextension of the PIP joint and flexion of the DIP joint .
  • ➤ Swan-neck deformity
  • ➤ rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ hyperextension of the PIP joint
  • ➤ flexion of the DIP joint

questions.text: Familial hemiplegic migraine type 1 is caused due to mutation in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) CACNA1A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Familial hemiplegic migraine type 1 is caused by mutations in the CACNA1A gene , which encodes a voltage-gated calcium channel.
  • ➤ Familial hemiplegic migraine type 1
  • ➤ CACNA1A gene

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic medications is contraindicated in individuals with medullary carcinoma of the thyroid or multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Liraglutide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ GLP-1 receptor agonists like liraglutide are contraindicated in individuals with a history of medullary thyroid carcinoma or multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2) due to the risk of medullary thyroid cancer.
  • ➤ GLP-1 receptor agonists
  • ➤ liraglutide
  • ➤ medullary thyroid carcinoma
  • ➤ multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN2)

questions.text: Felty’s syndrome is characterized by all of the following except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neutrophilia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Felty’s syndrome is defined by neutropenia , splenomegaly , and nodular rheumatoid arthritis . Neutrophilia is not a feature of this syndrome.
  • ➤ Felty’s syndrome
  • ➤ neutropenia
  • ➤ splenomegaly
  • ➤ nodular rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ Neutrophilia

questions.text: All of the following are involved in Polyarteritis nodosa, except?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pulmonary arteries

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN) , the pulmonary arteries are not involved , which is an important distinguishing feature of this vasculitis.
  • ➤ Polyarteritis nodosa (PAN)
  • ➤ pulmonary arteries are not involved

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Oxygen inhalation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is oxygen inhalation at 12 to 15 L/min via a non-rebreather mask.
  • ➤ treatment of choice
  • ➤ cluster headache
  • ➤ oxygen inhalation

questions.text: All of the following are features of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), except:
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DKA is characterized by metabolic acidosis with serum bicarbonate <18 mmol/L , hyponatremia , increased serum osmolality , and positive urine ketones . The correct answer is D , as bicarbonate levels are typically below 18 mmol/L in DKA.
  • ➤ metabolic acidosis
  • ➤ serum bicarbonate <18 mmol/L
  • ➤ hyponatremia
  • ➤ increased serum osmolality
  • ➤ positive urine ketones
  • ➤ D

questions.text: What is the most common pulmonary manifestation of Rheumatoid Arthritis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Pleuritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common pulmonary manifestation of rheumatoid arthritis is pleuritis , characterized by pleuritic chest pain and pleural effusion.
  • ➤ most common pulmonary manifestation
  • ➤ rheumatoid arthritis
  • ➤ pleuritis

questions.text: All of the following are true about isolated polymyalgia rheumatica, except?

options.label: B
options.text: Prompt therapeutic response to low-dose prednisone

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Rheumatoid factor is positive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR) , rheumatoid factor (RF) is typically negative , unlike in rheumatoid arthritis where it is often positive. The disease responds well to low-dose prednisone and is associated with increased ESR.
  • ➤ polymyalgia rheumatica (PMR)
  • ➤ negative

questions.text: All of the following are features of noninflammatory joint disorders, except?

options.label: B
options.text: Absence of inflammatory or systemic features

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prolonged morning stiffness

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prolonged morning stiffness is a feature of inflammatory joint disorders and not noninflammatory joint disorders , which typically present with mechanical pain, no synovial swelling, and negative lab findings.
  • ➤ Prolonged morning stiffness
  • ➤ inflammatory joint disorders
  • ➤ noninflammatory joint disorders

questions.text: What is the most common blood vessel involved in trigeminal neuralgia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Superior cerebellar artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The superior cerebellar artery is the most common blood vessel involved in trigeminal neuralgia , often causing compression of the trigeminal nerve and resulting in facial pain.
  • ➤ superior cerebellar artery
  • ➤ trigeminal neuralgia

questions.text: What is the most common feature of MEN 1?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Primary hyperparathyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common feature of MEN 1 is primary hyperparathyroidism , which is present in about 90% of patients and leads to hypercalcemia.
  • ➤ MEN 1
  • ➤ primary hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: Most common cause of myositis in those aged >50 years?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Inclusion body myositis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Inclusion body myositis (IBM) is the most common cause of myositis in individuals aged over 50, characterized by slowly progressive muscle weakness, particularly affecting the quadriceps and forearm muscles.
  • ➤ Inclusion body myositis (IBM)

questions.text: Which of the following ANA has Speckled pattern?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti Scl-70

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The speckled ANA pattern is associated with several antigens, including Anti Scl-70 , which is commonly seen in systemic sclerosis . Other antibodies, such as anti-Ro, anti-La, anti-Smith, and anti-Jo-1 , can also produce a speckled pattern.
  • ➤ speckled ANA pattern
  • ➤ Anti Scl-70
  • ➤ systemic sclerosis
  • ➤ anti-Ro, anti-La, anti-Smith, and anti-Jo-1

questions.text: What is the first manifestation of APS 1 (Autoimmune Polyglandular Syndrome type 1)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mucocutaneous candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first manifestation of APS 1 is most commonly mucocutaneous candidiasis , followed by hypoparathyroidism and adrenal insufficiency .
  • ➤ first manifestation
  • ➤ APS 1
  • ➤ mucocutaneous candidiasis
  • ➤ hypoparathyroidism
  • ➤ adrenal insufficiency

questions.text: All of the following are features of Inflammatory fluid in synovial fluid analysis, except?

options.label: A
options.text: Inflammatory fluid is turbid and yellow

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Presence of stringing effect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In inflammatory synovial fluid , the stringing effect is absent due to the reduction in viscosity. Other features include turbid and yellow appearance , polymorphonuclear leukocyte predominance , and elevated WBC count .
  • ➤ inflammatory synovial fluid
  • ➤ stringing effect
  • ➤ absent
  • ➤ turbid and yellow appearance
  • ➤ polymorphonuclear leukocyte predominance
  • ➤ elevated WBC count

questions.text: A patient presented with neck neck and back pain and the Xray is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH) is diagnosed by the presence of flowing ossifications over at least four contiguous vertebrae and is associated with back pain in elderly individuals.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female evaluated for Iron deficiency anemia. Her iron studies revealed following?
questions.explanation:
Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron-deficient erythropoiesis represents an intermediate stage in iron depletion, where the marrow lacks adequate iron for red cell production, but anemia may not yet be present.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters can be obtained by the following graph?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) FEV1/FVC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The flow-volume loop is primarily used to assess parameters such as FEV1/FVC to help evaluate pulmonary function and diagnose lung diseases.
  • ➤ flow-volume loop
  • ➤ FEV1/FVC

questions.text: All of the following are in favour of Psoriatic arthritis when compared to Rheumatoid arthritis, except?

options.label: D
options.text: Spine and sacroiliac joints are involved

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Arthritis is usually seropositive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psoriatic arthritis is usually seronegative for rheumatoid factor and anti-CCP antibodies, which contrasts with rheumatoid arthritis, where these markers are commonly positive.
  • ➤ seronegative

questions.text: Bulbar weakness and more frequent episodes of respiratory depression can be especially prominent in Myasthenia gravis with antibodies to?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) Anti-MuSK antibody

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-MuSK antibodies in Myasthenia Gravis are associated with bulbar weakness , respiratory depression , and neck weakness , and often require treatment with rituximab .
  • ➤ Anti-MuSK antibodies
  • ➤ bulbar weakness
  • ➤ respiratory depression
  • ➤ neck weakness
  • ➤ rituximab

questions.text: P-selectin-blocking monoclonal antibody used in sickle cell anemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Crizanlizumab

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Crizanlizumab is a P-selectin-blocking monoclonal antibody used in sickle cell anemia to reduce the frequency of vaso-occlusive crises.
  • ➤ Crizanlizumab

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is evaluated for a 5-year history of gradually progressive dyspnea and dry cough without wheezing or hemoptysis. He has not had fever or lost weight. He smoked one pack of cigarettes a day from the age of 18 to 60 years. He worked as a roofer for 40 years. Physical examination shows no digital clubbing or cyanosis. Auscultation of the lungs reveals bilateral end-inspiratory crackles. Pulmonary function testing shows: Total lung capacity - 67% of predicted, Residual volume - 72% of predicted, FVC-65% of predicted, FEVI-75% of predicted, FEV I/FVC ratio - 89% (Normal), DLCO - 52% of predicted. His chest radiograph is suggestive of Bilateral lower zone predominant lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Asbestosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most likely diagnosis in a patient with a history of asbestos exposure, progressive dyspnea, restrictive lung disease, and bilateral lower zone lung involvement is asbestosis .
  • ➤ asbestosis

questions.text: Hb Bart’s is defined as?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) γ₄

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hb Bart’s (γ₄) is an abnormal hemoglobin made up of four gamma chains and is typically seen in severe forms of alpha-thalassemia.
  • ➤ Hb Bart’s (γ₄)

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding repetitive nerve stimulation for Myasthenia Gravis?

options.label: A
options.text: Anti-AChE medication should be stopped 6–12 h before testing

options.label: B
options.text: It is best to test weak muscles or proximal muscle groups

options.label: C
options.text: In myasthenic patients, there is a rapid reduction of >10% in the amplitude of the evoked responses

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All are true

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Repetitive nerve stimulation in Myasthenia Gravis involves testing weak or proximal muscles, stopping anti-acetylcholinesterase medications before testing, and observing for a >10% decrement in the amplitude of responses.

questions.text: 60-year-old male being treated for Carcinoma prostrate presented with worsening breathlessness, chest pain and syncope. On arrival HR 125 with Shock index >1. CTPA confirmed diagnosis of pulmonary embolism. Cardiac troponin, BNP levels are normal. ECHO shows reduced RV function. Which of the following is recommended for in-hospital treatment of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  A) LMWH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cancer-associated pulmonary embolism , Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH) is the preferred in-hospital treatment due to its efficacy and safety profile.
  • ➤ cancer-associated pulmonary embolism
  • ➤ Low Molecular Weight Heparin (LMWH)

questions.text: Imerslund’s Syndrome is defined as?

options.label: A
options.text: Selective Malabsorption of folate with Proteinuria

options.label: B
options.text: Selective Malabsorption of Cobalamin with folate

options.label: C
options.text: Selective Malabsorption of Cobalamin with Proteinuria

options.label: D
options.text: Selective Malabsorption of Cobalamin with Lymphopenia

questions.correct_answer: C. Selective Malabsorption of Cobalamin with Proteinuria
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Selective Malabsorption of Cobalamin with Proteinuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome involves the selective malabsorption of cobalamin (vitamin B12) with associated proteinuria , leading to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • ➤ Imerslund-Gräsbeck syndrome
  • ➤ selective malabsorption of cobalamin (vitamin B12)
  • ➤ proteinuria

questions.text: Which of the following Hormone uses Receptor Tyrosine Kinase signalling?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulin uses receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) signaling , while hormones like growth hormone , activin , and TGF-β use different pathways (JAK-STAT and SMAD pathways, respectively).
  • ➤ Insulin
  • ➤ receptor tyrosine kinase (RTK) signaling
  • ➤ growth hormone
  • ➤ activin
  • ➤ TGF-β

questions.text: A 50-year-old gentleman with a family history of colorectal cancer presented with palpitations and syncope. On arrival ECG given below. What is not true about ECG finding in Pulmonary embolism?

options.label: A
options.text: Sinus tachycardia is the most common finding

options.label: B
options.text: S1Q3T3 is pathognomonic of Pulmonary embolism

options.label: C
options.text: T-wave inversion in septal and inferior leads suggest PE

questions.correct_answer: B. S1Q3T3 is pathognomonic of Pulmonary embolism
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) S1Q3T3 is pathognomonic of Pulmonary embolism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While the S1Q3T3 pattern can be seen in pulmonary embolism , it is not pathognomonic for the condition and may be seen in other situations involving right heart strain. The most common ECG finding in pulmonary embolism is sinus tachycardia , and evidence of right ventricular strain is crucial for diagnosis.
  • ➤ S1Q3T3 pattern
  • ➤ pulmonary embolism
  • ➤ sinus tachycardia
  • ➤ right ventricular strain

questions.text: Donath-Landsteiner antibody is characteristic of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paroxysmal cold hemoglobinuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Donath-Landsteiner antibody is a biphasic hemolysin characteristic of Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH) , causing hemolysis when red blood cells are exposed to cold and then warmed to body temperature.
  • ➤ Donath-Landsteiner antibody
  • ➤ Paroxysmal Cold Hemoglobinuria (PCH)

questions.text: A 45-year-old banker complains of shortness of breath (SOB) on climbing two flights of stairs. After one flight, he develops chest tightness and has had multiple syncopal episodes in the past. His past medical history is significant for deep vein thrombosis (DVT) due to limb immobilization 5 years ago. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) are normal, but his DLCO is reduced. ECHO shows right ventricular systolic pressure (RVSP) of 50 mmHg with normal left ventricular (LV) function. What is the most appropriate management strategy for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) CTPA (CT pulmonary angio)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a patient with a history of DVT , reduced DLCO , and elevated RVSP , the most appropriate next step is to perform CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA) to confirm the diagnosis of chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH) .
  • ➤ DVT
  • ➤ reduced DLCO
  • ➤ elevated RVSP
  • ➤ CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA)
  • ➤ chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension (CTEPH)

questions.text: Antibodies implicated in pathogenesis of Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Platelet factor 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The antibodies implicated in Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT) are directed against complexes of Platelet Factor 4 (PF4) and heparin, leading to platelet activation and a prothrombotic state.
  • ➤ Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT)
  • ➤ Platelet Factor 4 (PF4)

questions.text: A 60-year-old smoker presented with progressive breathlessness over 1 year. Chest X-ray (CXR) reveals hyperinflated lungs. Pulmonary function tests (PFTs) show moderate obstruction. Echocardiogram shows right ventricular systolic pressure (RVSP) of 60 mmHg. Which category of pulmonary hypertension does this patient belong to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) WHO Class III

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ This patient’s COPD -related pulmonary hypertension places him in WHO Class III , which is pulmonary hypertension due to lung diseases or hypoxia .
  • ➤ COPD
  • ➤ WHO Class III
  • ➤ lung diseases or hypoxia

questions.text: Single most powerful predictor of survival in Multiple myeloma?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) β2-microglobulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ β2-microglobulin levels are the most powerful predictor of survival in patients with Multiple Myeloma , reflecting both disease burden and kidney function.
  • ➤ β2-microglobulin
  • ➤ Multiple Myeloma

questions.text: ADAMTS13 activity levels of diagnostic of TTP ?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) <10%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A severe deficiency of ADAMTS13 activity (<10%) is diagnostic of Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) and distinguishes it from other thrombotic microangiopathies.
  • ➤ ADAMTS13 activity (<10%)
  • ➤ Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP)

questions.text: Thrombosis in which of the following is least likely to cause pulmonary embolism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Great saphenous vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thrombosis in the great saphenous vein (a superficial vein) is least likely to cause a pulmonary embolism, whereas thrombosis in deep veins such as the femoral or popliteal veins poses a higher risk for PE.
  • ➤ great saphenous vein
  • ➤ deep veins

questions.text: Maddrey discriminant function is calculated with?

options.label: A
options.text: 2.6 × [The prolongation of the prothrombin time above control {seconds}] + serum bilirubin [mg/dL]

options.label: B
options.text: 3.6 × [The prolongation of the prothrombin time above control {seconds}] + serum bilirubin [mg/dL]

options.label: C
options.text: 4.6 × [The prolongation of the prothrombin time above control {seconds}] + serum bilirubin [mg/dL]

options.label: D
options.text: 5.6 × [The prolongation of the prothrombin time above control {seconds}] + serum bilirubin [mg/dL]

questions.correct_answer: C. 4.6 × [The prolongation of the prothrombin time above control {seconds}] + serum bilirubin [mg/dL]
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 4.6 × [The prolongation of the prothrombin time above control {seconds}] + serum bilirubin [mg/dL]

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Maddrey Discriminant Function is calculated using the formula 4.6 × [prolongation of prothrombin time above control] + serum bilirubin and is used primarily to assess the severity of alcoholic hepatitis and the need for corticosteroid therapy.
  • ➤ Maddrey Discriminant Function
  • ➤ 4.6 × [prolongation of prothrombin time above control] + serum bilirubin

questions.text: Hy’s Law is used in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Drug-induced liver injury

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hy’s Law is used to predict severe outcomes in drug-induced liver injury (DILI) by assessing hepatocellular injury, elevated bilirubin, and excluding other causes of jaundice.
  • ➤ Hy’s Law
  • ➤ drug-induced liver injury (DILI)

questions.text: Gene defective in Dubin Johnson syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) ABCCA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The genetic defect in Dubin-Johnson syndrome involves the ABCC2 gene, which is responsible for impaired bilirubin transport, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.
  • ➤ Dubin-Johnson syndrome
  • ➤ ABCC2

questions.text: All are true regarding Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), except?

options.label: A
options.text: Often preceded by an upper respiratory infection, commonly with streptococcal pharyngitis

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) PT, aPTT are increased

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) , PT and aPTT are typically normal because the disorder is a vasculitis, not a coagulopathy.
  • ➤ Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP)
  • ➤ normal

questions.text: Clinically significant portal hypertension is defined as HVPG of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) >10 mmHg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Clinically significant portal hypertension is defined as a hepatic venous pressure gradient (HVPG) of greater than 10 mmHg , which is associated with complications like variceal bleeding and ascites.
  • ➤ portal hypertension
  • ➤ greater than 10 mmHg

questions.text: Virtually no VWF protein and usually FVIII levels <10% is seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Type 3 VWD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Type 3 VWD is the most severe form, characterized by virtually no VWF protein and very low factor VIII levels (<10%), leading to a severe bleeding phenotype.
  • ➤ Type 3 VWD
  • ➤ virtually no VWF protein

questions.text: Following Endoscopic image is diagnostic of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Eosinophilic esophagitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of concentric rings (trachealization) in the esophagus on endoscopy is highly indicative of Eosinophilic Esophagitis (EoE) , a condition often associated with allergies and presenting with dysphagia.
  • ➤ concentric rings (trachealization)
  • ➤ Eosinophilic Esophagitis (EoE)

questions.text: Cytogenetic rearrangement in Acute promyelocytic leukemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) t(15;17)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The characteristic cytogenetic abnormality in Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL) is the t(15;17) translocation , which creates the PML-RARα fusion protein and is a target for therapy with all-trans retinoic acid (ATRA).
  • ➤ Acute Promyelocytic Leukemia (APL)
  • ➤ t(15;17) translocation
  • ➤ PML-RARα fusion protein

questions.text: Following Esophageal pressure topography is suggestive of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Diffuse esophageal spasm

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A distal latency of less than 4.5 seconds on esophageal pressure topography is indicative of Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES) , which is characterized by uncoordinated contractions of the distal esophagus, leading to dysphagia and chest pain.
  • ➤ distal latency of less than 4.5 seconds
  • ➤ Diffuse Esophageal Spasm (DES)

questions.text: TKI active in the setting of the T315I mutation in Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML)?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ponatinib

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ponatinib is the TKI that remains effective in CML patients with the T315I mutation , which is resistant to most other tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
  • ➤ Ponatinib
  • ➤ T315I mutation

questions.text: Granulomatous colitis, oculocutaneous albinism, platelet dysfunction, and pulmonary fibrosis are seen in?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome is characterized by a combination of oculocutaneous albinism , platelet dysfunction , granulomatous colitis , and pulmonary fibrosis , distinguishing it from other genetic syndromes.
  • ➤ Hermansky-Pudlak syndrome
  • ➤ oculocutaneous albinism
  • ➤ platelet dysfunction
  • ➤ granulomatous colitis
  • ➤ pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: Doubling time in Burkitt’s lymphoma is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) <24 h

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The doubling time in Burkitt’s lymphoma is typically less than 24 hours , reflecting the highly aggressive nature of this lymphoma.
  • ➤ doubling time
  • ➤ Burkitt’s lymphoma
  • ➤ less than 24 hours

questions.text: Presence of scleral icterus indicates a serum bilirubin level of at least?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 3 mg/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of scleral icterus typically indicates a serum bilirubin level of at least 3 mg/dL .
  • ➤ scleral icterus
  • ➤ at least 3 mg/dL

questions.text: Which of the following is/are expressed in cells with Hairy cell leukemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) All of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL) , the leukemic cells express CD22 , CD103 , and CD25 , making these markers important for diagnosis and differentiation from other hematologic malignancies.
  • ➤ Hairy Cell Leukemia (HCL)
  • ➤ CD22
  • ➤ CD103
  • ➤ CD25

questions.text: A patient came for evaluation of ascites. His serum albumin is 3.5 g/dL, and his ascites fluid albumin is 1.8 g/dL. Which of the following can be a cause of ascites for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cirrhosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL suggests that the ascites is caused by portal hypertension , most commonly due to cirrhosis .
  • ➤ SAAG ≥ 1.1 g/dL
  • ➤ portal hypertension
  • ➤ cirrhosis
